metadata.case_name: Ms. Bhikusa Yamasa Kshatriya and Ms. Bastiram Narayandas v. Respondents

facts.text: Ms. Bhikusa Yamasa Kshatriya and Ms. Bastiram Narayandas, owners of bidi factories at Sangamner in the District of Ahmednagar, hereinafter referred to collectively as the appellants.

Appellants moved the High Court of Judicature at Bombay under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying for a writ or direction declaring s. 3(3)(iv) of the Minimum Wages Act, 1948, and Notification dated April 19, 1955, issued by the Government of Bombay, ultra vires, void and illegal.
High Court dismissed the petition on June 27 and 30, 1958 and November 28, 1958, holding that s. 3(3)(iv) and the Notification did not violate fundamental rights and procedure was followed.
Appeal preferred to Supreme Court with certificate of fitness under Art. 133(1)(c).
Minimum Wages Act, 1948 enacted to provide for fixing minimum rates of wages in certain employments. Employment in any tobacco (including bidi-making) manufactory in Part I of Schedule.
Government of Bombay by Resolution dated February 27, 1951, appointed Committee under s.5 to hold enquiry and advise on minimum wages for tobacco (including bidi-making) manufactory.
Committee consisted of three employers representatives, equal number of employees representatives and independent chairman.
On July 3, 1952, Government appointed Committee under s.6 to assist in considering revision of zoning and rates.
Advisory Board constituted by Resolution dated October 3, 1953.
Notification operative from March 31, 1952, issued under s.3(1)(a) fixing minimum rates in Zones I to IV. Ahmednagar in Zone III: Rs. 2/- for 1000 bidis without leaves in bidi making.
Notification dated June 30, 1955 under s.26(2) exempted bidi makers in Sangamner and Akola and within 7 miles for 3 months from July 1, 1955; extended till end of December 1956.
Notification dated August 22, 1956 cancelled exemption effective September 1, 1956 for Sangamner and Akola.
Notification dated April 19, 1955 revised minimum rates for Sangamner and Akola to Rs. 2/2/- for 1000 bidis after considering Advisory Committee report and consultation with Advisory Board.
Workers demanded revised wages; employers failed to pay; applications under s.20 to Regional authority.
Regional authority by order dated November 6, 1957 held workers entitled from January 1, 1957 but not before.
Nasik Bidi manufacturers (in Zone III) made representations dated June 17, 1955 and September 9, 1955 against revised rates citing economic depression etc.; implementation postponed.

legal_issues.text: Whether s. 3(3)(iv) of the Minimum Wages Act confers arbitrary and uncontrolled power upon the State Government to fix varying minimum rates for different localities, violating Art. 14 and Art. 19(1)(g).
Whether Notification dated April 19, 1955 is discriminatory and violates Art. 14.
Whether ss. 5,6,7,9 contravened as Committees and Advisory Board not validly constituted (no representatives of bidi employers in Advisory Board).

petitioner_arguments.text: s. 3(3)(iv) confers arbitrary and uncontrolled power to discriminate against employers in certain localities, violating equal protection (Art. 14) and right to carry on business (Art. 19(1)(g)).
Notification dated April 19, 1955 discriminatory and violates equality before law.
ss. 5,6,7,9 contravened; no representatives of employers in bidi industry in Advisory Board; no lawful revision.

respondent_arguments.text: s. 3(3)(iv) and Notification do not violate fundamental rights; procedure prescribed by Act followed.

court_reasoning.text: Act's scheme and purpose to prevent exploitation of labour; restraints on freedom of contract not unreasonable (citing Bijay Cotton Mills).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fixation of minimum wages does not violate Art. 19(1)(g).

court_reasoning.text: Diversity of conditions necessitates delegation; policy inherent in Act; procedure under ss.4,5 provides guidance; no arbitrary power (citing Kathi Raning Rawat).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classification based on local conditions rational and has nexus with object.

court_reasoning.text: Notification followed full enquiry, reports, representations; intelligent differential with rational nexus.
Committees and Board constituted per s.9; Advisory Board not required to have industry-specific reps; performed coordinating function.

holdings.text: s. 3(3)(iv) does not contravene Art. 19(1)(g) or Art. 14.
Notification dated April 19, 1955 does not violate Art. 14.
Constitution of Committees and Advisory Board did not contravene statutory provisions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bijay Cotton Mills Ltd. v. The State of Ajmer
precedents_cited.relevance: Minimum Wages Act does not infringe Art. 19(1)(f); restraints reasonable to prevent exploitation.

precedents_cited.case_name: U. Unichoyi v. The State of Kerala
precedents_cited.relevance: Act prevents exploitation; capacity of employer not considered in fixing minimum wages.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kathi Raning Rawat v. The State of Saurashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Delegation valid if policy/principles for guidance; reasonable classification permitted.

statutes_cited.name: Minimum Wages Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Authorizes fixation/revision of minimum wages by locality; prescribes procedure via committees; applied to bidi industry; exemption and claims handled.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Equal protection; right to carry on trade/business; writ jurisdiction; appeal certificate.

outcome.summary: The appeal is dismissed. The Supreme Court upholds the High Court's dismissal, holding s.3(3)(iv) of the Minimum Wages Act and the Notification dated April 19, 1955 valid and not violative of Arts. 14 or 19(1)(g); committees properly constituted.

key_quotes.text: The object of the Act is to prevent exploitation of the workers, and for that purpose it aims at fixation of minimum wages which the employers must pay.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purpose and policy of Minimum Wages Act.

key_quotes.text: By entrusting authority to the appropriate Government to determine the minimum wages for any industry in any locality or generally, the legislature has not divested itself of its authority, nor has it conferred uncontrolled power upon the State Government.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies delegation under s.3(3)(iv) as guided by Act's policy.

key_quotes.text: Power to fix minimum rates of wages does not by itself invest the appropriate Government with authority to make unlawful discrimination between employers in different industries.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies no inherent discrimination in locality-based rates.
